qas.question: Why did the government refuse to allow the London Underground stations to be used as shelters?

answers.text: interfere with commuter and troop travel

qas.question: Underground officials were ordered to lock the stations during raids but opened how long after the orders?
In 1940 how many people were sleeping in the Underground stations?
Muffling the sound of batter made what easier in the Underground Stations?
Why were many killed in Underground Stations?

context: The most important existing communal shelters were the London Underground stations. Although many civilians had used them as such during the First World War, the government in 1939 refused to allow the stations to be used as shelters so as not to <a0_0>interfere with commuter and troop travel<a0_0/>, and the fears that occupants might refuse to leave. Underground officials were ordered to lock station entrances during raids; but <a1_0>by the second week<a1_0/> of heavy bombing the government relented and ordered the stations to be opened. Each day orderly lines of people queued until 4 pm, when they were allowed to enter the stations. In mid-September 1940 about <a2_0>150,000 a night<a2_0/> slept in the Underground, although by the winter and spring months the numbers had declined to 100,000 or less. Noises of battle were muffled and <a3_0>sleep<a3_0/> was easier in the deepest stations, but many were killed from <a4_0>direct hits<a4_0/> on several stations.
